title: Don't Burn Me!
content:
Zhou Ze scooped up a handful of water and splashed it on his face, then slowly raised his head, looking at himself in the mirror, slightly haggard. As an Emergency Room doctor, this haggardness seemed like a standard feature.

"Dr. Zhou, a new patient will be here soon, looks like they fell from a building, not sure if it was a suicide!" Nurse Wang Ya shouted from the entrance of the men's restroom.

"Got it, I'll be right there," Zhou Ze responded, then pulled out a tissue, wiped the water droplets dry, and started walking out.

The ambulance quickly drove into the hospital. Lying on the stretcher was an elderly man dressed in a grey Tang suit. The old man was coughing incessantly, occasionally coughing up bloody foam and fragments of spleen tissue, his entire body covered in bloodstains.

Zhou Ze immediately ran over, pushing the stretcher while observing the patient's condition, and at the same time shouted to the people ahead: "Prepare surgical instruments, quickly!"

The patient's condition was very poor.

"I... I... don't want to die."

The old man opened his eyes, looking at Zhou Ze, who was closest to him.

"Don't worry, you'll be fine. We'll help you, you won't die."

Most critically ill patients say things like this at such times; after all, those who can truly face death calmly are few. And as a doctor, this is certainly not the time to analyze the patient's condition and tell them their chances of survival. What the patient needs at this moment is psychological comfort.

"No... no... down... down... down there is really too terrifying..."

The old man suddenly clutched Zhou Ze's wrist, looking at Zhou Ze with a solemn expression.

"Calm down, relax, your life won't be in danger." Although his wrist was aching, Zhou Ze still didn't try to pull free.

"I don't want... don't want to go down there again... They... they found me... I... they found me..."

"Hiss..." Zhou Ze suddenly felt a sharp pain in his wrist.

"Dr. Zhou, your hand!" The young nurse beside him immediately cried out.

The old man's fingernails were very long, and for some unknown reason, they were black—a translucent black like amber, not like dirt was accumulated within them.

And at this moment, the old man's fingernails had already embedded themselves into the flesh of Zhou Ze's wrist.

"I'm not going down... not going down... not going down... Haha... cough cough cough..."

The old man suddenly straightened up and coughed violently. Immediately after, his body trembled, the hand that was gripping Zhou Ze's fell away, and his entire body became still.

"Prepare for resuscitation!" Zhou Ze shouted.

The old man was pushed into the Emergency Room. Doctors and nurses began resuscitative measures, and the defibrillator was also ready.

"Dr. Zhou, let me treat your wound for you," Wang Ya said, walking over at this moment.

As doctors, they weren't actually worried about this minor flesh wound. What they worried about most was if the old man had other diseases, which could put the doctor at risk of occupational exposure. After all, there was a lot of blood on the old man's hand just now, and no one knew if he had any infectious diseases.

Some diseases, if contracted, could ruin a lifetime.

After the wound was bandaged, another doctor walked out of the Emergency Room and shook his head at Zhou Ze.

This meant the person couldn't be saved.

Everyone's mood was somewhat down, but for them, such things were common, and they would quickly adjust.

"Dr. Zhou, you should get checked out," Wang Ya suggested.

"No, I have something else tonight." Zhou Ze shook his head, walked straight to the changing room to change his clothes, then went to the hospital parking lot and drove away.

The car had just driven under the Jianghai Avenue overpass when Zhou Ze's phone rang.

"Hello, this is Zhou Ze."

"Dr. Zhou, the children are all waiting for you."

"My apologies, Principal Wu, a patient delayed me. I'm on my way now, please ask the children to wait for me a little longer."

"Okay, okay." The other end quickly hung up the phone.

Zhou Ze checked the time again; it was already 8:30 PM. The children at the orphanage usually went to bed very early.

The red light turned green. Zhou Ze pressed the accelerator and drove through.

"HONK!!!!!!!!"

And at this very moment,

A heavy truck ran the red light and drove over. Zhou Ze only had time to turn his head and look at the blinding high beams outside the car window,

Immediately after,

"CRASH!"

The world spun,

The small car, like a fragile piece of white paper before the heavy truck, was directly sent flying, and after tumbling several times in the air, it crashed to the ground.

............

"Ugh..."

Zhou Ze woke up.

He found that his body was completely unable to move, as if it was stuck.

At the same time, his eyes couldn't open. He knew he had been in a car accident, a very serious one. Out of professional habit, he wanted to check his injuries immediately, but he couldn't move.

All around, there were occasional sounds of other vehicles passing by, and various honking sounds.

Am I still at the accident scene?

Am I still in the car?

Zhou Ze thought to himself.

Soon,

The wail of police sirens came, along with the sound of fire trucks.

Finally, the familiar siren of an ambulance reached Zhou Ze.

Zhou Ze sensed his body being moved. The temperature nearby was a bit high; they must be cutting his car to rescue him.

Zhou Ze had participated in many such rescue operations, and was familiar with some of the procedures.

What a pity. The cake in his back trunk and the orphanage children's Children's Day party were now ruined.

"Dr. Zhou!"

A familiar voice.

It must be Dr. Chen from the hospital.

Zhou Ze let out a long sigh of relief in his heart. At least he had saved his life. This could count as an unforeseen calamity, right?

There were also sounds of several nurses nearby, but because the surroundings were too noisy, Zhou Ze couldn't hear clearly.

But then, one sentence from Dr. Chen sent Zhou Ze's heart plummeting!

"Dr. Zhou has lost his vital signs."

No,

I'm not dead!

I'm not dead yet!

I'm not dead!!

Zhou Ze screamed desperately in his heart!

He wasn't dead, he was still conscious, he wasn't dead!

Next, Zhou Ze sensed someone performing CPR on him. He felt each heavy compression, but he couldn't open his eyes, nor could he speak.

He wasn't dead.

He hoped they would quickly realize he wasn't dead!

But after a flurry of activity,

Zhou Ze heard the sound of several nurses he knew crying.

Dr. Chen punched a nearby car door, appearing utterly distraught.

Hey!

Don't give up!

Absolutely don't give up!

I'm not dead!

I must be in a state of suspended animation,

Excessive blood loss?

Severe injury?

But I'm really not dead!

I should still be breathing, I should still have a heartbeat!

Zhou Ze roared frantically in his mind.

But next, he sensed himself being lifted onto a stretcher, and presumed he was being placed inside the ambulance.

Immediately after, came the sound of the ambulance driving away.

The nurses in the ambulance were still crying.

But their crying was particularly grating in Zhou Ze's ears.

He wasn't dead.

Why are you crying!

Why cry!

Look at me again,

Look at me again,

Check again,

I'm not dead!

The ambulance stopped.

Immediately after, Zhou Ze heard the hospital leaders speaking:

"So Young Zhou is just gone?"

"The accident was very serious. Dr. Zhou was severely injured, lost too much blood, and has been confirmed dead."

"Really? He's just gone like that?" Another Vice President still couldn't believe it.

"Young Zhou is gone." This was the voice of a department head. "I just checked again."

I'm not dead!

You quacks!

I'm not dead!

You bastards!

Bastards!

Zhou Ze cursed relentlessly in his heart. At this moment, the people around him were no longer his colleagues, nor his friends, let alone his leaders or elders.

They had actually determined that he was dead,

But can a dead person still hear sounds and feel things?

I'm not dead!

You bastards!

Animals!

Sons of bitches!!!!!

I'm not dead!

Save me!

Save me!

The stretcher began to move. It was quiet all around, and the temperature was gradually dropping.

"Xiao Ya, don't be too sad. The President said the hospital will hold a memorial service for Dr. Zhou tomorrow."

"Sister Suqin, I just can't believe it, someone is just gone like that. Dr. Zhou was such a good person, how could he just be gone?"

"There's no telling what the weather will bring, and misfortune can strike at any time. Just try to see things clearly."

After saying these things, the two nurses left.

All around,

It was empty.

That chilling coolness,

Was so clear.

Zhou Ze struggled incessantly, constantly wanting to resist. He wanted to wake up, he desperately longed to make a sound.

But his current feeling was like being "pressed by a ghost"*, no matter how hard he tried, his body was simply beyond his control.

Finally,

He gave up in despair.

He was tired,

And exhausted.

He knew where he was now,

In the hospital's,

Morgue.

..................

When Zhou Ze "woke up" again, he sensed a faint coolness on his face and a distinct stinging sensation.

"Is the makeup done?" someone asked nearby.

"Don't rush, wait. He was hit so badly, how could the makeup be done that quickly?"

"The hospital is rushing us; they're about to send him to the memorial service."

"Why don't you do it then?"

The mortician seemed a bit annoyed and applied the makeup with more force. Of course, their clients were dead people; dead people naturally wouldn't feel pain, nor would they complain, so they just needed to show results to the living.

Zhou Ze no longer had the strength to struggle.

He just lay there quietly,

Enduring the stinging sensation of the makeup brush pressing repeatedly on his face.

Finally,

The makeup was finished.

"Alright, tell them to come in. We're done with our work."

Zhou Ze felt himself being dressed. Immediately after, he was pushed out, and the hospital orderlies lifted him into a soft, confined space.

This,

Must be a cooling coffin.

Then, all the surrounding noise was instantly cut off.

The lid must have been closed.

Shaking,

Swaying,

Bumping...

He didn't know how much time had passed, but Zhou Ze finally heard sounds again. The cooling coffin lid must have been opened.

What he heard,

Was funeral music.

The hospital President was giving a speech with a microphone, praising him, lamenting his loss,

Then came the Vice President, department heads, and so on.

Around him,

There were occasional sounds of footsteps.

Some just quietly walked past, taking one last look at him,

Others tried to call his name a few times, their voices choked with sobs.

This was the viewing of the remains.

Viewing,

My remains!

I'm not dead,

I'm really not dead,

I'm not dead yet!

Not dead!

Zhou Ze wailed in his heart,

He started trying again,

But it was still no use.

He could only hear and feel,

But he couldn't speak,

Nor could he open his eyes.

Everyone believed he was dead,

But he knew clearly,

He wasn't dead yet!

The children from the orphanage also came, crying by his side.

Their tears were sincere, because Zhou Ze himself had grown up in an orphanage. For this reason, after starting work, most of his salary was donated to the orphanage. This car accident also happened because he was rushing back to the orphanage that evening to celebrate Children's Day with the children.

"Young Zhou, rest in peace. This time, you died in the line of duty. You don't have family, but your compensation will be given to the orphanage, so rest assured," the Vice President said, standing by Zhou Ze's side.

Subsequently,

Zhou Ze sensed himself being isolated again. The cooling coffin lid must have been closed once more.

Then came another period of bumping,

Finally, it stopped.

The cooling coffin lid was opened again.

All around, it was somewhat quiet. Occasionally, human voices could be heard, but they weren't noisy.

Two people, one holding his shoulders and the other his legs, lifted him up, and placed him on another cold rack, which felt like a steel plate.

These two people were very skillful, extremely skillful.

Around him, there were faint, indistinct sounds of crying.

At first, Zhou Ze couldn't discern where he was now,

But at this moment,

He suddenly understood.

Bastards!

They had sent him to the crematorium!

They were going to burn him!

I'm not dead, you bastards!

Fuck your ancestors!

I'm not dead!

Not dead yet!

Don't cremate me!

Don't cremate me!

I'm really not dead yet!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!

You animals!

Bastards!

Sons of bitches!!!!!

This time, it was Zhou Ze's most frenzied and most frantic moment.

He knew,

Once he was cremated,

There would be no turning back!

He would directly face death!

A complete and utter end!

He was unwilling, he truly was unwilling. He was not yet thirty; he hadn't started a family; he didn't have children yet; he still had a life to live; he still had a long way to go!

"Mommy, I just saw this uncle's hand move," a little girl's timid voice rang out nearby.

"SMACK!" A small slap landed.

"Don't talk nonsense! I'll deal with you when we get home," the girl's mother rebuked.

Zhou Ze despaired.

Because no matter how he struggled,

No matter how he roared in his heart,

The people outside could not perceive it.

He was placed on the conveyor belt.

The machine started,

He was being pushed forward.

He knew what he was about to face,

And because of this, he was utterly terrified!

No,

No,

No!

I'm not dead, I'm really not dead!

Don't burn me!

Don't burn me!

No one could hear his pleas.

They were only responsible for being sad,

Only responsible for grieving,

Only responsible for completing this procedure,

And then going home for dinner, and continuing with their lives tomorrow.

Finally,

Zhou Ze sensed himself being pushed into a narrow place full of the smell of oil residue.

Immediately after,

A viscous liquid was sprayed onto his body.

He knew what this was,

It was gasoline.

Immediately after,

"Sizzle..."

Hot!

Extremely hot!

Pain,

Intense burning pain!

Fire,

Fire,

Great fire,

Fire everywhere............

---
*   "Ghost pressing on bed" (鬼壓床): A common Chinese term for sleep paralysis, a temporary inability to move or speak while falling asleep or waking up.

title: The Live-in Son-in-Law
content:
On the midnight street, the streetlights were yellow, and people were flustered. It was very cold, and the wind, like knives cutting skin, was biting.

Zhou Ze also felt cold. He didn't know where this was again, but he knew one thing: this was... the human world.

He had already died, but he had returned. He didn't know what he should do, and could only mechanically, numbly continue walking forward.

He currently didn't have the time to think about too many other things, such as the place he had just descended to, such as the old man he had treated before the car accident, such as the faceless woman in the pool wearing a red dress, such as... his fingernails.

He had returned, which should have been a very joyous thing, but even if someone occasionally walked by, even if he tried his best to greet them, still no one could see or hear him.

He was excluded by this world, cut off. People who hadn't experienced "solitary confinement" wouldn't understand the pain of complete isolation, and for Zhou Ze, the entire world right now was his cage, and the cage was covered with a black cloth.

No one could see him, nor could anyone communicate with him; he couldn't pick up anything tangible, and even, even the wind could easily blow right through him.

He was so frail. The term "too weak to withstand a gust of wind" was truly not an exaggeration for him.

Moreover, what shocked and horrified Zhou Ze the most was that he could see faint points of light constantly dispersing from his body; in other words, his body was slowly fading.

Perhaps in another fifteen minutes, he would completely vanish, with the last insignificant trace of him erased.

He didn't know how all of this had happened, but he was clear that he truly didn't have much time left.

Among the Eight Immortals, Iron Crutch Li entered the body of a person who had starved to death and fallen, thus becoming the image passed down through later generations.

Zhou Ze had also heard stories about ghosts "borrowing a corpse to return a soul," and he also wanted to "borrow a corpse to return a soul." He was very cold and also very panicked; he needed a physical body to attach himself to.

He didn't even mind who this person was. People at this time are always selfish, and Zhou Ze was no exception. Moreover, he truly couldn't take it anymore.

However, whenever he prepared to approach someone, a fiery glow would appear above that person's head and on their shoulders, directly preventing him from getting close. He even suffered harm because of it, accelerating his "evaporation" speed.

He was a bit tired, and a bit numb. He was waiting for his end, waiting for his finish.

As someone who had already died once, facing death again made him a bit more composed instead.

Moreover, given Zhou Ze's current situation, continuing to linger here, the longer he lingered, meant the longer he would endure torture.

"Creak..."

Ahead, there was a storefront still lit up, appearing to be a bookstore, because through the glass door, rows of bookshelves could be seen inside.

Someone pushed the door open from inside and walked out. It was a man wearing a hoodie. The man wore a hat, so his true face couldn't be clearly seen. After looking around for a while, he left in a hurry.

Of course, the man couldn't see Zhou Ze, who was standing less than five meters away from him.

Originally, Zhou Ze didn't feel anything unusual, but shortly after the man left, Zhou Ze suddenly sensed a warm aura from inside the bookstore.

Yes, a warm aura.

This warmth made Zhou Ze somewhat puzzled, but he was currently like a person about to freeze to death who suddenly received a box of matches; even if he knew the matches couldn't save his life, he would still strike one to feel the last bit of warmth before dying.

Zhou Ze walked over there. His body passed directly through the bookstore's glass door, continued inside, and arrived behind the bookstore's bookshelves.

Behind the bookshelves, lay a person, a handsome young man, probably twenty-three or twenty-four years old. Because the air conditioning was on in the shop, he wasn't wearing many clothes, just a long-sleeved shirt and a light jacket.

He lay on the ground, but on him, Zhou Ze sensed a warm feeling, like a pauper walking on the road at night and picking up a bag of gold coins.

This attraction was irresistible, and Zhou Ze, in his current state, also had no right to refuse!

Zhou Ze walked over and crouched down in front of this young man. He didn't know how to enter the other person's body, but he understood how to touch the warmth he needed.

One hand reached out, placed on the other person's chest. Zhou Ze saw his fingernails slowly embed themselves into the other person's body. This was a very eerie feeling, different from the "breeze" blowing through his body when he walked on the road earlier. This was a fusion, a merging using his fingernails as a medium.

Slowly, Zhou Ze's entire being began to enter the other person's body. The two began to overlap.

………………

"Xu Le! Wake up, wake up!"

Zhou Ze was awakened by a series of shoves. No, to be precise, he was "startled." He opened his eyes and found himself sitting behind the bookstore counter, with his hands previously resting on it.

"Hey, wake up!"

The woman's voice was sharp, very high-pitched, and carried an air of command.

Raising his head, Zhou Ze looked at the woman in front of him. No, to be precise, it should be a girl, probably high school age. Although she was a "big girl," she still hadn't completely shed her childishness.

"Hey, Xu Le, what exactly do you mean? You've got guts now, huh? Want to give my parents and my sister attitude, huh? You actually dared not come home all night last night! Who gave you such guts?!"

Xu Le?

Who is that?

Zhou Ze spread his hands in confusion, finding them very smooth. His previous hands had developed some calluses from long hours of practicing with surgical instruments, but these hands had none.

"Hey, I'm talking to you!"

The girl slapped the counter, her manner aggressive.

Zhou Ze frowned slightly, stood up, and walked to the glass mirror by the shop door. He saw his reflection, an unfamiliar face. No, he had seen this face before; it was the face he had seen last night.

This body, is mine now?

"Hey, what do you mean? My parents are angry, and my mom's still throwing a tantrum at home. Let me tell you, everything you eat, drink, and use now is from my family. What right do you, a live-in son-in-law, have to put on airs in my house? Who are you trying to put on a show for?! If you dare not come home again tonight, believe me, I'll come over and smack you!"

The girl made a gesture to raise her palm, but she suddenly realized that the man in front of her, her "brother-in-law," didn't dodge or beg for mercy as he usually did. Instead, the look in his eyes made her feel somewhat scared.

At this point, she looked at the time and found it was already seven-thirty.

"Hmph, I'm going to school first. I'll settle scores with you tonight!"

The girl left huffily.

Zhou Ze slowly sat back down on the chair behind the counter. There was an old laptop here, and a phone next to it.

Even now, he still hadn't adapted to the process of his identity change.

He was Zhou Ze, a famous young surgeon in Tongcheng. Moreover, he was an orphan.

As a result, he had now become this identity. What did that girl just say? I'm... a live-in son-in-law?

Have a wife? And a mother-in-law and father-in-law?

And judging by the attitude and tone of his "sister-in-law" just now when speaking to her "brother-in-law," his status as a "live-in son-in-law" truly adhered to excellent ancient traditions.

A live-in son-in-law, commonly known as a "reverse marriage" arrangement, was not only looked down upon by his wife's family but also by everyone around him in ancient times. Their status was even similar to criminals; during the Han and Tang dynasties, those forced to serve on the frontier often included such men.

He picked up the phone. The phone had no password set; he didn't know if that guy was lazy or dared not set a password, but at least at this moment, it allowed Zhou Ze to easily open his WeChat and QQ.

The QQ contacts list had few people: just a few middle school, high school, and university classmates. Then there was a family list, with only one person, noted as "Wife."

He opened the QQ chat history with her: empty.

Alright, Zhou Ze opened WeChat, tried searching, and found the woman noted as "Wife." Here, there were replies. They were basically Xu Le asking about various things, such as what to eat tonight, what needed to be prepared tonight, how much money was needed for inventory, how much the bookstore had recently sold, how her health was—a whole bunch of questions.

And the other party's replies were often very perfunctory and very aloof, consisting of: "Oh." "Mm." "Okay."

Zhou Ze tossed the phone aside. This interpersonal relationship was a bit complicated. He suddenly looked at his palm; his fingernails were no different from an ordinary person's.

But in matters like the old man he had treated before the car accident, his escape from the faceless woman, and his entry into this guy's body, his fingernails had played an extremely crucial role.

As his mind willed, just then, Zhou Ze found his fingernails slowly growing longer, and at the same time becoming jet-black and translucent. There was even a faint black mist swirling around them.

"Whoosh......"

He let out a long breath, closed his eyes, and when he opened them again, his fingernails had returned to normal.

From morning until noon, Zhou Ze sat there, trying to adapt to his new identity and calm the sense of discomfort brought by his identity change. He didn't even eat lunch, unsure if he had forgotten or simply didn't feel hungry at all.

This was still Tongcheng. Zhou Ze's old home was in Chongchuan District; now he was in Gangzha District, not far away.

By afternoon, Zhou Ze finally sighed, quietly stood up, and decided to accept what had happened.

He began to try cleaning the bookshelves. In any case, he might as well find something to do for himself first.

The old man who had choked him before dying had said "he's been discovered," and the faceless woman in hell had said "you'll be caught sooner or later," which created a sense of crisis in Zhou Ze's heart.

His current state was considered "barely living." To die and be resurrected was a heaven-sent blessing, so he cherished it. At least, before he fully understood the situation and gathered enough clues, he had to embrace this identity. It was best not to cause too much anomaly, and not to attract the attention of those "who wanted to catch him."

This shop's business was truly bad. The slump in the traditional book market hadn't been a one- or two-day affair for a long time, and this place wasn't even on the prime "golden street" right outside a school gate.

One could only say that Xu Le choosing to open a bookstore here, whether it could break even was a question in itself.

It wasn't until three in the afternoon that the day's first customer walked in.

The customer wandered around the children's books section, and wandered for a long time.

Zhou Ze waited for a while, then still walked over and asked, "What kind of topic are you looking for?"

"Just browsing," the other party replied.

"Mm." Zhou Ze then ignored him, as he hadn't yet fully integrated into the role of "bookstore owner."

But just then, the other party suddenly walked behind him and spoke eerily:

"You really don't recognize me?"

"What?" Zhou Ze asked.

"Last night, I hit you on the head with a baseball bat and robbed you of your money. And I even deliberately checked, you clearly had no breath left then."
